Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic 117
Colophon: "This is the day of completing the Holy Gospel, on Saturday in the Ninth Hour from the day [Nones, i.e. 3 pm] 31 in the month of Kānūn al-Awwal [December] in the Year of the World [Anno Mundi] 6701, and Arsani the guilty copied it…" (f. 138v).
Incipit: نبتدي علیٰ بركة الله و حسن توفيقه نكتب الانجيل المقدّس (f. 3r).
Explicit: هذا يوم كمال الإنجيل المقدّس (f. 138v).
Illustrations note: Headpiece on ff. 3r, 22r (tailpiece) | Anthropomorphic decoration on f. 22r

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic 127
Colophon: "This Blessed Gospel was completed on Saturday the Feast of St Philip, which is 14 in the month of Tishrīn ath-Thānī [November] in the Year of Our Father Adam [Anno Mundi] 6xxx, [which was] the year 1xxx after Divine Incarnation…, [which was also] 14 of Dhī al-Ḥijjah of the Arab Year [AH] 390. O Reader, remember this humble amongst [the Children of the] Baptised, the monk Paul the Egyptian by name who narrated/translated? and copied it…." (f. 241v).
Incipit: نبديَ بعون الله و حُسن توفيقه نكتب الإناجيل المقدّسة ألّتي تقرأ في مدار السّنة (f. 2r)؛ بدو أناجيل لوقا ألّذي أكرز بالإسكندرية (f. 81v)؛ بدو قرآأت إنجيل مرقس (f. 116r).
Explicit: نجز هذا الإنجيل المبارك (f. 241v).
Illustrations note: Minor geometric headpieces throughout, beginning on ff. 81v
Inscription: Reader inscription, f. 1v  | Donation inscription, f. 241v

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic 162
Contents note: Credo followed by prayers to be recited during liturgy ; An account of a celestial epistle which fell at Rome during the Patriarchate of Athanasius ; The Assumption of the Virgin ; The Story of Onesima daughter of the Emperor | Tables on ff. 1v-23v
Colophon: "The [copying of] Acts of Apostles, Seven Catholic Epistles, and Pauline Epistles were finished on Holy Thursday 16 in the month of Ādhār [February–March] after Divine Incarnation [Anno Domini] 1348…" (f. 232v).
Incipit: نبتدي بعَون الله و حسن توفيقه نكتب كتاب الأبركسس أي أعمال الرّسل (f. 24v)؛ نبتدي بمعُونة الله و توفيقه نكتب الرّسايل الكاثوليكية (f. 78v)؛ نبتدي بعوُن ربّنا و مَخلصَنا أیسوع المسيح نكتب بيان خبر بولص الرّسول (f. 105r)؛ نبتدي بعوُن الله و حسن توفيقه نكتُب تفاسيرالرّسايل البولصیّة (f. 233v).
Explicit: كمل بعون الله و حسن توفيقه كتاب أعمال الرّسل القدّيسين المعروُف بالأبركسس (f. 78r)؛ كملت الرّسايل السَّبعَة الكاثوليكية (f. 105r)؛ نجزت بمعوُنة الله و حسن توفيقه أعمال الرّسل و السَّبعَة الكاثوليكية و الرّسايل البولصية (f. 232v)؛ … الكتاب المبارك الأصل و التّفسير … [تو]فيقه (f. 291v).
Inscription: Donation inscription, f. 1r | Reader inscriptions, etc., ff. 78r, 233r, 291v
Condition note: ff. 290–291 and back board split in half.

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic 281
AltTitle.other: Commentary on the Book of Genesis by St. John Chrysostom
AltTitle.uniform: John Chrysostom, Saint, -407. Homilies on Genesis
Author: John Chrysostom, Saint, -407
Colophon: "Here was completed with the aid of Allah the Most High [the copying of] the explication of our father senior amongst the saints, John Chrysostom, of the First Book of the Torah; and together they are sixty-six treatises, [the completion of] which was on Monday 20 in the month of Ushbāṭ [January–February] in the Year of the World [Anno Mundi] 6731. ‘Abdullah ibn al-Faḍl ibn ‘Abdullah translated it from the Greek language into the Arabic language, and it was copied at Saint Chariton [Pharan] Monastery…" (f. 384r–385v).
Explicit: تمّ بمعونة الله تعالیٰ (f. 385r).

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic 445
Descriptive title: Mimars, Lives of Saints, Martyrdoms, Canons, Calendars, and other treatises
Author: John Chrysostom, Saint, -407
Contents note: Codex containing 30 Miscellaneous Mimars, Lives of Saints, Martyrdoms, Canons, Calendars, and other treatises. These may be classi­fed in the following categories: 1 - Mimars by SS. John Chrysostom, Ephraem  the Syrian, Mark, Theodore and Epiphanius.  2-Two treatises on the determination of dates and of Cyclus. 3 -  Apopthegmata  derived  from the sayings of St. Moses of Scetis. 4 - Canons of St. Andrew Bishop of Crete, of the Apostles, of Clement Pope of Rome, and of other Fathers of the church. 5 - Stories of the Prophet Elias, investiture of St. Peter, the Apostles Matthew and Andrew, St. Paul the Apostle, St. Simeon Stylite, St. Eulogius the Quarryman, St. Christopher, Philip the Apostle, Tadry the merchant and Abraham the Jew of Constantinople. 6 - Epistle of Abgar King of al­ Ruha and the answer to it. 7 - Martyrdom of SS. Cyprian and Justina, and of St. Anthony who perished in the city of al-Raqqa during the reign of Hariin al-Rashīd. 8 - Commemoration of Events in Jesus Christ's life during the reign of Pontius Pilate. 9 - Various items containing the book of the "Synodikia" an astrological treatise connected with Christmas, and the benediction of circumcision and marriage

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic 482
Author: John Chrysostom, Saint, -407|~|John, of Damascus, Saint|~|Gregory, of Nazianzus, Saint|~|Athanasius, Saint, Patriarch of Alexandria, -373
Contents note: Mimars selected from SS. Andrew of Cyprus, John Chrysostom, John Damascene, Epiphanius, Gregory the Theologian and Athanasius. Martyrdom of SS. Longinus the Centurion, Artemius, Jacob the Persian, Ignatius and Febronia of Nisibis. Hymn by St. Luke companion of St. Paul, encomium by St. Arcadius Archbishop of Cyprus. A commentary on the Life of St. John Damascene. An elegy sent by St. Dionysius to St. Timotheus on the occasion of the martyrdom of SS. Peter and Paul

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic 531
Descriptive title: Martyrdoms and Lives of Saints | Mimars
Contents note: Codex containing seventeen miscellaneous treatises which may be divided into the following categories: 1 - The Revelation of St. Paul. 2 - Lives of Saints beginning with that of the anonymous saint surnamed “God’s Man”. Other Lives include those of St. Marina, St. John Damascene, and St. Paul during his encounter with Satan. 3 - Martyrdom of St. Barbara and two anonymous Saints during the wars of Heraclius and Chosroes the Persian. 4 — Mimar by St. Anastasius Bishop of Mt. Sinai, two theological epistles by Paul Bishop of Sidon to some Muslims, two anonymous sermons and twelve Troparia. 5 - Miracles of Our Lord. 6 - Story of the Icon of Our Lady in the Monastery of Saidanaya. 7 - Story of the discovery of the Holy Cross of the Passion by St. Helena. 8 - St. Eustratius on the sack of Jerusalem and the capture of the Holy Cross of the Passion together with Zacharias Patriarch of Jerusalem

Contents note: Preceded by the following miscellaneous treatises: 1 - Book of Problems and Responses between Abbot Antiochus and St. Athanasius I Patriarch of Alexandria (53 Problems and Responses). 2 - Three Lives of Saints and Miracles of SS. John of the Golden Gospel, Theodore and Basil Bishop of Caesarea. 3 - Story of the Incarnate Icon of Our Lady in the Monastery of Saidanaya. 4 - Mystical table with aphorisms. 5 - Three tracts derived from the writings of SS. John Chrysostom, Basil the Great and Ephraem the Syrian on miscellaneous topics. 6 - Poem in praise of the Holy Land by Abd al-Masifi. 7 - History of Lent and Easter

Explicit: قد تمّ إنجيل القدّيس متّیٰ البشير ألّذي كرز بالعبرانية في السّند و الهند (f. 30r)؛ تمّ إنجيل مرقس القدّيس البشير ألّذي كرز بالرّومية في مدينة رومية الكبيرة (f. 48r)؛ تمّ إنجيل لوقا البشير الّذی تكلّم باليونانية في مدينة الإسكندرية (f. 79r)؛ تمّ إنجيل يحنّا البشيرألّذي كرز باليونانية في إفسس (f. 102r)؛ و كان كمال كتابه (f. 222r).

Illustrations note: Decorative border/tailpiece on f. 102r
Inscription: Inscriptions on f. 222v, back pastedown (f. 223r)

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic 80
Incipit: نبتدي بعون الله سبحانه نكتب الإنجيل المقدّس (f. 2r)؛ نبتدي بعون الله و حسن توفيقه نكتب بشارة الرّسول مرقص الإنجيلي (f. 53v)؛ نبتدي بعون الله سبحانه و تعالیٰ نكتب الإنجيل المقدّس من بشارة الرّسول لوقا الإنجيلي (f. 82r)؛ نبتدي بعون الله سبحانه نكتب إنجيل يوحنّا (f. 128v)؛ نبتدي بعون الله سبحانه نكتب فصول الأناجيل (f. 166r).
Explicit: كمل … بشارة المرقص الإنجيلي الّذي كتبهُ في رومية علی[؟] عهد بطرس الرّسول (f. 81v)؛ كمل … بشارة المرسول الإنجيلي يوحنّا الفاضل، المتکلّم بالاهيّات، المحبوب من الرّب، و بتمامها. كمل نسخة الإنجيل المقدّس (f. 165r)؛ كمل … نسخة فهرسة و سنكنساري الإنجيل المقدّس (f. 192v).

Inscription: Donation inscription, f. 192v | Reader inscriptions, ff. 193r, 194r, 194v | Supplicant and reader inscriptions, f. 193v

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic 89
Incipit: نبتدي بعَون الله و حُسن توفيقه و ارشاده و تسديده. نكتب الاربعة الأناجيل المقدّسة. الاوّل من ذلك بشارة القديس متّی الإنجيلي. (f. 2r)؛ فاتحة بشارة الرّسول المُعظّم مرقس الإنجيلي الطّاهر البشير (f. 51ar)؛ نبتدي بعَون الله و حُسن توفيقه و ارشاده و تسديده نكتب بشارة القدّيس لوقا الإنجيلي. (f. 79v)؛ إبتدا بشارة القدّيس يوحنّا الإنجيلي (f. 127r)؛ نبتدي بعَون الله نكتب فصول الأناجيل الّتي يقروا في طَول الخمسين (f. 164r).
Explicit: كمل نسخ بشارة الرَسول العظيم متی الإنجيلي و لله السبح و المجد دايماً و علينا رحمته امين (f. 49v)؛ كملت الاصحاحات و عددها و السبح لرب المجد دايماً سرمداً و علينا رحمته امين (f. 50v)؛ كمل إنجيل القدّيس مرقس البشير الّذي كتبه برومية في عهد بطرس الرّسول و المجد لله دائماً ابداً (f. 78v)؛ و السّبح لله دايماً و علينا رحمته آمين (f. 125r)؛ تمّت الاصحاحات الّتي الإنجيل لوقا القدّيس البشير الإنجيلي ترحمنا[؟] الرّب لشفاعته آمين (f. 126v)؛ كملت هذه النّسخة المقدّسة بحبل الله المقدّس طور سينا (f. 163r)؛ كمل بعون الله و رحمته کتبة السّنكسار (f. 193r).
Inscription: Reader and supplicant inscriptions, f. 1r | Reader inscription, f. 193v | Inscription (Coptic?), f. 194v

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic 93
Contents note: Tables on ff. 2r-7v
Incipit: نبدي بعَون الله و توفيقه بكتابَة فهرسة اصحاحَات البشارة المقدّسة الّتي قالها الرّوح القدس علیٰ فمّ متّیٰ (f. 8v)؛ فَاتِحَةُ بَشَارَةُ مَتَّیٰ اَلْإِنْجِيلي (f. 10v)؛ فاتحة بشارة الرّسُول المُعظّم مرقس الإنجيلي بَطْريرَك الإسكندرية (f. 79v)؛ نبدي بعون الله و حُسن توفيقه ننقل انجيل لوقا البشير من اللّسان اليوناني إلي العربي (f. 118v)؛ فاتحة إنجيل الرّسول النّبيل المعظّم لوقا الإنجيلي أحد الرّسل السّبعين (f. 121v)؛ بعون الله تبارك و تعالیٰ نبتدي و بحسن توفيقه و ارشاده نهتدي نذكر إصحاحات إنجيل يوحَنّا الرّسول العظيم الثاولوغس (f. 188v)؛ فاتحة إنجيل الرّسُول العظيم يوحنّا الثاولوغُس أَحد الرّسُل الأثنیٰ عَشر (f. 189v).
Explicit: كُملت الفهرسة المباركة و لله منّة و الشّكر آمين (f. 10r)؛ كمل نسخ بشارة العظيم متّیٰ الإنجيلي و لله السّبح و المجد دائماً (f. 74r)؛ تمّت فهرسة و المجد دائماً لربّ المجد (f. 120v).

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic 99
Colophon: "Copying finished on Friday 28 in the month of Ḥazīrān [June] in the Year of the World [Anno Mundi] 6794, which was at Holy Mount Sinai Monastery" (f. 211r).
Incipit: نبديَ بعون الله و حُسن توفيقه بكتابة فهرسة اصحاحات البشارة المقدّسة الّتي قالها الرّوح القدس علیٰ فمّ متثیٰ (f. 2r)؛ فاتحة بشارة متثَیٰ الإنجيلي (f. 3v)؛ فاتحة بشارَة الرّسُول المُعظّم مرقص الإنجيلي بَطْريرَك الإسكندرية (f. 66v)؛ نبدِءُ بعون الله و حُسن توفيقه ننقل انجيل لُوقا البشير من اللَّسان اليُوناني إلي العَربي (f. 104v)؛ فاتحة إنجيل الرّسُول النّبيل المُعظّم لُوقا الإنجيلي أحد الرّسل السّبعين (f. 106v)؛ فاتحة إنجيل الرَّسُول العظيم يُوحنّا الثاولوغُس أَحد الرّسُل الأثنا عَشر (f. 167v).
Explicit: هي[؟] الفهرسة المباركة و لله المنّة[؟] و الشّكر آمين (f. 3r)؛ كمل نسخ بشارة الرّسول العظيم مثّیٰ الإنجيلي و لله السّبح و المجد و الاكرام دايماً ابداً آمين (f. 65r)؛ تمّت الفهرسة و المجد دايماً لرَبُّ المَجدُ (f. 105v)؛ كُمِلت فهرسة الإصحاحات و المجدُ لله دائماً أبداً آمين (f. 167r)؛ و كان الفراغ من نَسخُه (f. 211r).
Inscription: Donation inscription, f. 2r

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic NF M 12
Descriptive title: Works of John Chrysostom | Works of Ephrem | Lives and martyrdoms of saints
Author: John Chrysostom, Saint, -407|~|Abū Qurrah, Thāwdhūrus, approximately 750-825
Contents: 1. St. John Chrysostom concerning prayer; 2. Work of St. Basil the blessed teacher; 3. St. Mark on repentance; 4. Work of Ephrem containing twenty nine articles; 5. Mimar concerning the authenticity of the Gospels by Theodorus bishop of Harran; 6. From the work of St. John Chrysostom, its incipit: "if you sit reading the word of God then entreat him and pray that your eyes open your heart"; 7. From the work of St. Ephrem, he distinguishes between good and evil; 8. From the work of John Chrysostom on repentance; 9. Exegesis of Lord's prayer which our Lord Christ taught his disciples in the Gospel; 10. Exegesis of Beatitudes by St. John Chrysostom; 11. The Beatitudes spoken by our Lord Jesus in the holy Gospel; 12. Exegesis of the faith of the central Church; 13. From the work of St. John Chrysostom on the body; 14. The martyrdom of Peter, leader of the Apostles and disciple of Christ; 15. Story of saints Cyranes and Justine; 16. Story of St. Euphrosyne; 17. Story and martyrdom of the blessed and kindly St. Barbara; 18. The story and martyrdom of saints Sophia and her daughters; 19. The story and martyrdom of the blessed saint Mar Georgios; 20. The story of Xenophon and his wife Mary and their two sons John and Arcadius; 21. From an account of St. John Chrysostom concerning Mary and Martha and their brother Lazarus, the Prophet Elias, and Hell, and what he said concerning profit;  22. From an account of Mar Ephrem concerning the Transfiguration of our Lord Christ on Mt. Tabor, the holy mountain, the blessed mountain, the greatest mountain; 23. From an account of the blessed St. John Chrysostom concerning the cross and the departure of Adam our first ancient father from the Garden by the word of God; 24 From an account of St. Mar Ephrem ... incipit: "O loved ones, O brothers, who is able to speak and pronounce all that must be concerning the wonders of our Lord and our God Jesus Christ"; 25. From an account of St. John Chrysostom concerning the Apostle John; 26. From an account of St. Chrysostom concerning spiritual love; 27. Account of Mar Ephrem concerning fasting

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic NF X 30
Contents: 1. Thirty-ninth sermon: We ought to build a home free of rot by taking up moral virtues; 2. Fortieth sermon: We ought not to extend our battles beyond our power for the sake of God; 3. Forty-second sermon: On concord and love; 4. Forty-third sermon: We ought to spend our days of holy fasting in rest and ease; 5. Forty-fourth sermon: On sudden departure from this worldly life; 6. Forty-fifth sermon: We ought not to surrender ourselves to adversity; 7. Forty-sixth sermon: We ought to imitate the suffering of the Lord; 8. Forty-seventh sermon: Report on the Christians killed in Bolghan for their refusal to eat meat during Lent; 9. Forty-eighth sermon: On the dominion of our Lord Jesus Christ and his incarnation; 10. Forty-ninth sermon: On the Annunciation to the Virgin Mary; 11. Fiftieth sermon: The Passover prefigures the future, eternal Passover in patience and courage; 12. Fifty-first sermon: On always celebrating and keeping the Passover for the sake of God; 13. Fifty-second sermon: We ought to be renewed after having received news of our coming trials, both perceptible and imperceptible; 14. Fifty-third sermon: We ought to endure any punishment in imitation of Christ and his holiness; 15. Fifty-fourth sermon: We ought to guard ourselves from the deception of Satan; 16. Fifty-fifth sermon: On righteous suffering and the lessons of humility and patience; 17. Fifty-sixth sermon: On the suffering of our Lord and Master Jesus Christ; 18. Fifty-seventh sermon: On the rebuke of brothers who have transgressed and a lesson and sermon on discipline.

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic NF X 4
Descriptive title: Works on Church history and theology of Christian denominations
Author: Antiochus, monk of Palestine, active 7th century
Contents: 1. Mimars of Antiochus the monk of the Holy Larva of Mar Saba to Eustathius an abbot of the monastery known as Attaline in the city of Ankara in Galatia whose abbots number one hundred and thirty (of which we have the following five: {126}. Concerning the call of God, {127}. Concerning the fear of God, {128}. Concerning divine love, {129}. Concerning the role of prophecy, {130}. Concerning the Kingdom of Heaven); 2. Treatise regarding the Seven Holy Councils (from the first to the seventh); 3. Explanation of the beliefs of the Nestorian, Jacobite, Maronite, Arianistic, Macedonian, Armenian; 4 . Explanation of the beliefs of St. Theodore, bishop of Harran known as Abu Qurrah; 5. Also his treatise on regarding the meaning of the beliefs of the Orthodox Christians and the Oneness of the Creator and the denial of the shameful accusation which their opponents level against them without merit; 6. Response against those trangessing the faith of proper orthodoxy

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Arabic NF X 50
Contents: 1. Tenth sermon: On death; 2. Eleventh sermon: On the spiritual harvest and the unceasing progeny of the servants of Christ, read during the harvest; 3. Twelfth sermon: On abstinence from ephemeral pleasures; 4. Thirteenth sermon: We ought to preserve the beauty of the unpolluted soul, read during Transfiguration and Repentance; 5. Fourteenth sermon: On death; 6. Fifteenth sermon: On the commemoration of St. John Archbishop of Chalcedon; 7. Sixteenth sermon: On the gift of God and his boundless love; 8. Eighteenth sermon: We ought not to give ourselves up to the sufferings of disgrace; 9. Nineteenth sermon: On spiritual cultivation; 10. Twentieth sermon: On fidelity; 11. Twenty-first sermon: On Christ's concern for us; 12. Twenty-second sermon: On eternal judgment; 13. Twenty-third sermon: On the birth of the Savior; 14. Twenty-fourth sermon: On the migration from this world; 15. Twenty-fifth sermon: On virginity.

Title: Sinai, St. Catherine’s Monastery, Syriac NF M 9
Descriptive title: Memra on the Contest of Job | Memre of Ephrem on Uriah the Hittite and David the King  | Memra of Isaac the Teacher on the Antichrist | Memra of Jacob on the Antichrist’s Teaching | Memra on Mar Daniel by Mar Ephrem
Related: Cf. NF frag 30
AltTitle.other: Memra of Mar Jacob on the Antichrist’s teaching while the Holy Apostles warred against him
Author: Ephrem the Syrian, Saint, 303-373|~|Jacob, of Serug, 451-521
Contents note: The Memra on the Antichrist and its attributed author Isaac the Teacher are otherwise unknown. Philothée, p. 293 attributes this work to Isaac of Amid.
Illustrations note: On f. 44v, under the rubric, there is drawn in red ink a waving line, like a serpent, the head of which ends in a cross. It appears opposite the words “O jealousy how bitter you are!”
Script note: Estrangelo script, regular and well aligned on both sides
